metadata.sermon_title: A Gospel For Those Who Are Afraid
metadata.bible_text: John 6:20 (with references to Matthew 8:23-27 / Mark 4:35-41 and Isaiah 43:1-3)
metadata.sermon_start_end: The gospel is good news. The whole gospel is good news for all of our desperate questions, for all of our poignant needs, for all of our mute pleas, for all of our fitful moods and gloomy emotions. The gospel is also good news for all of our anxieties [...] O Israel, Fear not, for I have redeemed thee, I have called thee by thy name; thou art mine. When thou passest through the waters, I will be with thee; and through the rivers, they shall not overflow thee; when thou walkest through the fire, thou shalt not be burned.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on a single specific passage. While it starts with John 6:20, it immediately conflates it with the Synoptic version of the storm (where Jesus is asleep), then wanders into the Old Testament (Moabites, Isaiah) and general psychological observations. It treats the Bible as a source of 'ideas' about fear rather than recreating a specific text into a new word.
quotes: There is an arresting scene about fear in the New Testament.
Jesus... lay asleep. (Note: In John 6, the cited text, Jesus is not in the boat asleep; he walks on water. The preacher is using Matthew/Mark/Luke instead).
There was a day in Jewish history when the nation was under peril of invasion from the Moabites...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Stick to the specific mechanics of John 6:20. In John, Jesus is not in the boat; he approaches from the outside. This 'nowhere else' detail is ignored in favor of a general 'Jesus in the storm' narrative.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is some attempt to set the scene (Sea of Galilee geography), but it remains at the level of 'color' rather than substantive theological exposition. The preacher does not engage with the specific Johannine context of the 'I Am' (Ego Eimi) statement, which is central to the Greek text.
quotes: The sky-blue surface of this calm and placid lake is six hundred feet below sea level...
sudden winds whipping from the valleys... can fan these peaceful waters into wild and frothing waves.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Analyze the Greek 'Ego Eimi' (It is I / I AM). Dekker requires the preacher to know the languages to uncover what the text meant for the first readersâ€”specifically the divine self-revelation of Jesus.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is broad and touches on the zeitgeist (modern city life, narcotics, anxiety), which Dekker values. However, it often veers into general psychological truths rather than applications derived strictly from the text's authority.
quotes: We are afraid for our children, since they must live in a nervous, jittery age when the evil of war and the danger of narcotics may prey on their bodies and minds.
The psychologists tell us that one of the dangers of our fears is that they get repressed...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move from general psychological advice (repressed fears) to the specific theological claim of the text: how the presence of the 'I AM' specifically addresses the modern 'spiritually displaced person'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured more like a thematic speech than an interwoven exposition. It uses the Bible passage as a springboard for a three-point lecture on fear. The hearer is not 'expounded' together with the text; the text is used to illustrate the preacher's points.
quotes: First, it gives us the status of possessed people. Second, the gospel gives us a place where we can air our fears... And then, the gospel gives us a partner...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Abandon the 'three-point' thematic structure. Let the movement of the biblical narrative dictate the movement of the sermon so that exposition and application happen simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon takes human 'misery' (fear, sin, treachery) seriously and points to 'redemption' (being owned by God). It avoids being 'too objective' by focusing on the human subject's experience before God.
quotes: there lurks in each of us a deep marsh of evil and sin, of treachery and betrayal.
To have no relationship to anybody big enough to protect us is perhaps reason for terror.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' part is somewhat thin. The sermon ends on 'strength' rather than the specific life of gratitude/service that flows from being 'more than conquerors'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon lacks the 'two ways' almost entirely. While it mentions 'being lost in time' (adrift, spiritually displaced), it lacks the sharp call to responsibility or the ultimate seriousness of the destination. It feels 'safe'.
quotes: They feel themselves adrift, spiritually displaced persons, wandering aimlessly across the face of their years.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher should address the 'lostness' of the 'flight to false freedom' more sharply as a choice with eternal or temporal consequences, rather than just a 'nervous' condition.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'telos' and is presented as the one who makes the difference. However, the sermon occasionally slips into treating Jesus as a 'partner' or 'companion' (psychological categories) rather than the Lord who is God (theological category).
quotes: The point of the narrative being that Christ is more than a match for our fears.
We have a partner... a friend who does not go 'a piece of the way' but to the end.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Emphasize the 'two natures' more clearly. Christ is not just a companion 'in the boat'; He is the Lord of the elements who says 'I AM'. The grace must be more clearly 'salvation outside ourselves'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,250 words, the sermon would take about 12-13 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker (Thesis 8), this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of the text and the cultural analysis to reach at least 20 minutes. The current brevity leads to a 'thematic' treatment rather than a deep 'boring' into the specific Scripture.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its thematic nature and lack of textual specificity. It treats the Bible as a collection of illustrations for the theme of 'fear' rather than an authoritative word that must be uniquely expounded. The length is insufficient for the depth Dekker demands, and the 'two ways' are virtually absent. However, it succeeds in its psychological seriousness and its focus on the human subject (misery/redemption).
strengths: Strong psychological awareness that connects with the 'zeitgeist' of anxiety and modern city life.
Effective use of the 'three parts' (misery/redemption) to ground the gospel in human experience.
Avoids 'general truths' in the description of fear, making the 'misery' concrete.
weaknesses: Lack of textual fidelity; conflates different gospel accounts and ignores the specific 'nowhere else' features of John 6.
Insufficient length (approx. 12 minutes) fails the 'depth needs breadth' requirement.
The 'two ways' are not addressed; the sermon lacks the urgency of a life-and-death choice or the possibility of being lost.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is more of a 'religious speech about the gospel' than a 'sermon' according to Dekker's strict definition. It lacks the rigorous exposition of a specific pericope and the necessary duration to achieve true homiletical depth.
